title: Teaching Hotels: Why You Might Want to Stay In One
text:
IMAGINE A HOTEL staffed primarily by college students. What comes to mind? A concierge ready to advise on the neighborhood’s cheapest nachos? A lounge permanently set up for beer pong? Housekeeping you’d best not examine too closely, if my old dorm is at all representative?

But teaching hotels—the hospitality-school equivalent of a teaching hospital, where students put classroom theory into real world practice—are more than “Animal House” with embroidered towels. During a recent visit to Ithaca, N.Y., I stayed at Cornell University’s on-campus Statler Hotel, run by their School of Hotel Administration. For more than 90 years it’s brought Ivy-League rigor to the hospitality arts. Alongside the professional staff, more than 200 students work in the hotel, from the valet stand to the manager’s office. Students wear name tags that identify which of the university’s colleges they attend and their projected graduation date. Alex Susskind, the school’s associate dean for Academic Affairs, said the 153-room hotel “is as important to us as any other part of our educational program.”

My room, outfitted with Frette towels and robes, was clinically clean. Hanging in the closet near the robes was a “Giving Bag,” a student-conceived initiative that lets guests donate to charity any usable items they choose to leave behind. Downstairs, the hotel’s Regent Lounge featured locally produced wine and beer and spirits, like Finger Lakes Distilling’s McKenzie Bourbon, which my server—a biology student—recommended in an Old Fashioned.

“ ‘The more difficult guests teach kindness and patience.’ ”

The student staffers I encountered appeared to treat their work seriously, which made sense; for most of them it was more than just a part-time gig, it was the foundation of a career. “I started off working in housekeeping doing laundry, turndown and public areas,” said Nathan Harkins, a Hotelie, as students and graduates of the School of Hotel Administration are called (the hotel’s gift shop sells gear with the term spelled out in Cornell’s signature red block letters). Mr. Harkins finagled his way into revenue management meetings, then worked his way up to the position of student director of rooms. He hopes to ascend to student general manager before he graduates in 2020.

Students also see us guests as more than just clients; we’re curriculum. In the Netherlands, students at the Hotel Management School Maastricht put in time at the 26-room Teaching Hotel Château Bethlehem, where “every guest can teach the students something,” said Eline Rademaker, the hotel’s director of marketing and sales. “The more difficult guests teach kindness and patience. The ‘easiest’ ones teach about not becoming too informal with guests.”

A lot of the lessons with which the students grapple are not readily apparent to guests. At the Conrad N. Hilton College of Hotel and Restaurant Management at the University of Houston, students don’t just help run the university’s Hilton hotel, where they comprise 70% of the staff. They’re also involved in the planning and execution of a $30.4-million expansion, said the college’s dean, Dennis Reynolds (a Hotelie himself.) “We had a semester-long class where they did the design [for a brewpub],” said Mr. Reynolds, “and a semester-long class where they did the business plan.” Hopefully, by the time the pub opens, the designers will be old enough to toast their accomplishments with a beer.

These accommodations aren’t particularly cheap. Room rates at teaching hotels typically align with those of other full-service accommodations (rates at the Statler Hotel start at around $265 a night). The value proposition is in the service. A teaching hotel, after all, is never, ever understaffed. “When you have seven people at the front desk checking in two people, that’s not the model for making a lot of profit,” said Mr. Reynolds. “When Hilton executives come and visit us, I get an earful every time.” His response? “We’re a teaching hotel—that’s the whole idea.”

GUEST STARS / Tips From Hospitality-School Deans, Alum and Other Pros on Acing Your Next Hotel Stay

How to get an upgrade?

Illustration: FEDERICA DEL PROPOSTO

“Ask if a different [or] better room is available. If a hotel is not full and won’t be during your stay, the marginal cost for an upgrade to the hotel is small,” said Alex Susskind, associate dean for Academic Affairs at Cornell University’s School of Hotel Administration. In his book “Heads in Beds,” author and former hotel employee Jacob Tomsky suggests one way to make your ask more persuasive. “Money. Cash on the desk...Even if I can’t find an upgrade proper, I will put you in the very best room of your category...There is always a better room, and when I feel that twenty burning in my pocket, I will find it for you.”

What to tip the housekeeper?

A budget or midprice hotels, Mr. Susskind says he leaves a couple of dollars per night. “Upscale and above, $5 or so per night,” he added. But don’t just leave the cash. “Make sure to leave a note so [your housekeeper] can be sure that it is for them,” said Nathan Harkins, Cornell University’s School of Hotel Administration, Class of ’20. “Want your housekeeper to actually love you? Strip all of the sheets of the bed and leave them in a pile, leave your towels in a pile.”

Beyond tipping, how can you reward above-and-beyond service?

“Many hotels have incentive programs by which the employee will get credit for review mentions: recognition in a staff meeting or some sort of prize,” said Mr. Harkins, so “mention their name in a review on TripAdvisor or whatever website you used to book the room.”

Things go wrong. When is an apology not enough?

“It all depends on the severity,” said Dennis Reynolds, dean of the University of Houston’s Conrad N. Hilton College of Hotel and Restaurant Management. “If the Wi-Fi fails for an hour, I think an apology is sufficient. If the hotel system fails because of planned construction and the hotel didn’t tell the guests, then we’ll probably need to discuss the appropriate solution, which might be a drink coupon, free dessert or even a meal.”
description: At teaching hotels, including Cornell University’s Statler, you don’t just get top-of-the-class service, you’re part of the lesson plan. Plus: Hotel pros on how to score an upgrade and other tips on acing a hotel stay.
